newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks drop 91 points, more selling seen.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks drop 91 points, more selling seen.

text.p: Toronto stocks tumbled with Wall Street on Thursday, as fear of rising interest rates and lofty stock prices prompted heavy selling.
The TSE 300 Composite Index sank 91.40 points to close at 6165.81, extending its recent slide. The key index lost 48 points on Wednesday.
Trading was heavy with 89.5 million shares changing hands worth C$1.3 billion ($950 million).
"We have a combination of markets discounting 1997 earnings and the risk of higher interest rates in the United States," said CIBC Wood Gundy chief strategist Subodh Kumar.
All but one of Toronto's 14 sub-groups lost ground at the close of trading on Thursday. The heaviest losses were in communications, consumer products and conglomerates.
Canada's major banks also continued to selloff after hitting record highs in recent months. The only gaining sector was gold, up a meager 20 points.

Stronger-than-expected U.S. retail sales data on Thursday heightened fears that the U.S. Federal Reserve may raise interest rates to ward off inflation. Looking ahead on the TSE, Kumar said: "I think we're still in a pull-back phase."
* BioChem Pharma Inc. was the top net loser, sinking 8.10 to 70.50 after the biotechnology firm reported disappointing fourth quarter results on Wednesday.

* Bre-Minerals Ltd. led heavy traders, falling 0.30 to 17.25 on 2.9 million shares. Other big traders included Petro-Canada, down 0.35 to 19.80 on 2.4 million shares, and BCE Inc. which fell 2.30 to 65.80 on 1.2 million shares.
* Among the banks, Toronto-Dominion Bank dropped 0.75 to 38.15, while Royal Bank of Canada dipped 0.60 to 58.80.
* Cobre Mining Co. jumped 4.49 to 5.00 on 1.2 million shares after a merger with Aurex Resources Corp. was approved by the Toronto Stock Exchange on Thursday.
